p: The volatile profile from this species is very close to those of C. aurantium and C. sinensis, and a little less so to C. grandis and C. reticulata ( Figure 3), and further apart from the other species studied. As in C. sinensis, numerous sesquiterpene hydrocarbons in have been reported in C. paradisi ( Figure 2 and Supplementary Table S2), such as the sesquiterpene Î±-cedrene, isolated in C. paradisi ( Njoroge et al., 2005b), C. grandis ( Njoroge et al., 2005b), C. sinensis ( Njoroge et al., 2005a; Sawamura et al., 2005), C. aurantifolia ( Minh Tu et al., 2002a), and C. medica ( Wu et al., 2013).
